security: Revealing operational details such as the methods used for exfiltration attempts, code names (AMLEO-3, KUBARK), and the identities of individuals involved (AMBIG-4, Mario REMIS) could compromise ongoing or future operations. Exposing the use of assets and their roles (e.g., AMBIG-4 not being identified as a KUBARK asset) could endanger these individuals and disrupt intelligence-gathering activities.  Quoting the document, 'KUBARK was desirous of having him insure that the M/V ADA was not permitted to carry out further family rescue missions to Cuba at this time' reveals the CIA's attempts to control or prevent independent actions, potentially creating diplomatic issues if exposed.
summary: A dispatch regarding the unsuccessful exfiltration attempt by M/V ADA in May 1964, sponsored by AMLEO-3 to rescue his family from Cuba, detailing the events, individuals involved, and inconsistencies in the accounts.
summary_one_paragraph: This secret dispatch from the Chief of Station, JMWAVE, to the Deputy Chief, WH/SA, reports on the failed exfiltration of AMLEO-3's family from Cuba via the M/V ADA between May 9-12, 1964. Frustrated by KUBARK's discontinued efforts to assist him, AMLEO-3 independently organized the mission, enlisting Mario REMIS, Daniel (RODRIGUEZ) Santos (owner of the M/V ADA), Armando BLANCO Lorenzo, Romelio LOPEZ Sosa, and AMBIG-4. The mission failed due to detection by Cuban authorities and resulted in injuries, arrests, and operational inconsistencies; AMLEO-3, motivated by desperation, remains determined to continue independent exfiltration attempts despite the risks, prompting JMWAVE to ensure the M/V ADA is prevented from further missions.
title: Operational/TYPIC/AMLEO Unsuccessful Exfiltration Attempt by M/V ADA, 9-12 May 1964
